Description of the CMOFS gridding algorithm

The CMOFS method described below, allows to strictly determine the influence of each data, used for gridding. This can be done by set the priority levels for each data. For example, we can think, what data in scattered data points are most precise and must be taken first. Information about surface behavior between data points is less reliable and we should use it at last step. Each time, we use CMOFS algorithm we must build "priority classification" for data. This classification determines the influence of each data in gridding procedure.

We try to build function as cells of equidistant grid with values:

where are the values in the cells needs to determine, - set of basis functions:

Here is the breif scheme of CMOFS algorithm:

  • Classify all data to extent of truth: from less truth until indirect apriori information
  • Write functionals for each data type. This functional describes the way of taking the data into account. Functional order must corresponds to data classification, created before.
  • Minimizing first functional . There are several possible results:
    • All unknown values was found, the solution complete.
    • The only part of unknown values was found one-valued, other coefficient are undetermined.
    • No one of coefficients was one-valued determined.
  • The second functional can be minimized in two ways:
    • By finding conditional extremum:

    • If functional doesn't depends on undefined coefficients, then functional extremum can be found from solving system of linear equations

      Note: derivatives of already determined must not be calculated.

Using described CMOFS algorithm surfit implements the following functionals:

Name Description Functional Example

func ordered data points

where cell (i,j) is the same as func's cell (I,J).

map_func.tcl

defarea domain of the function

where cell (i,j) is the same as defarea's cell (I,J).

map_defarea.tcl

task scattered data points - set of scattered data points,

where point with coordinates belong to the cell (i,j)

map_task.tcl

area area with constant value described with closed 2D piecewise linear curve

where (i,j) - indexes of the cells in area, z - area constant value.

map_area.tcl

iso piecewise linear isoline

where (i,j) - indexes of the cells crossed with isoline, z - isoline value.

map_iso.tcl

cntr 3D piecewise linear curve

where (i,j) - indexes of the cells crossed with contour, - mean value of contour for the (i,j) cell.

map_cntr.tcl

fill_with sets value for all undefined cells

where (i,j) - indexes of the undefined cells, - value for filling.

completer describes surface behaviour in areas without any data. The first summand tells that surface must tend to constant surface, the second - surface must tend to plane.

where integration changes with summation, differentiation with finite-difference analogues.

all examples here

trend trend surface (a kind of completer)

where integration changes with summation, differentiation with finite-difference analogues.

map_trend.tcl

wfunc ordered data points

modifies completer or trend functional with adding summand with "informational weight"

where cell (i,j) is the same as wfunc's cell (I,J).

map_wfunc.tcl

wtask scattered data points - set of scattered data points, - informational weight for p-th point.

modifies completer or trend functional with adding summand

where point with coordinates belong to the cell (i,j)

map_wtask.tcl

warea area with constant value described with closed 2D piecewise linear curve modifies completer or trend functional with adding summand with informational weight :

where (i,j) - indexes of the cells in area, z - area constant value.

map_warea.tcl

wiso piecewise linear isoline modifies completer or trend functional with adding summand with informational weight :

where (i,j) - indexes of the cells crossed with isoline, z - isoline value.

map_wiso.tcl

wcntr 3D piecewise linear curve modifies completer or trend functional with adding summand:

where (i,j) - indexes of the cells crossed with contour, - mean value of contour for the (i,j) cell, - mean informational weight of contour for the (i,j) cell.

map_wcntr.tcl

flt tectonical fault line To take fault line in terms of grid, fault line transforms to grid based line using modified Brezengham algorithm. After that fault line presented as a set of cell borders.

Modifies completer or trend functional: the summands, for which two neighbour cells have the "faulted" borders will be removed from the functional.

map_flt.tcl

surfit constructs the functional sequence using priority variable and internal order of presented functionals:

  • defarea
  • flt
  • task
  • wtask
  • iso
  • wiso
  • cntr
  • wcntr
  • area
  • warea
  • func
  • wfunc
  • trend
  • fill_with
  • dynamic
  • completer
Consider one factitious example:

$ load libsurfit[info sharedlibextension]
$ iso_load iso.dat
$ set priority 1
$ task_load task.dat
$ wtask_load wtask.dat
$ set priority 2
$ trend_load trend.dat
$ completer_set 2 1

According to this script, surfit loads data to the memory and constructs the functional sequence:

  1. iso
  2. task
  3. trend
  4. completer + wtask

This sequence means that the first data to take into account is isoline, next task, then trend. At the last is completer with wtask (wtask will modify completer functional).


surfit-1.0.0pre
